definition: to insult/to direct bad language at sb/to slag off

sentences.english: A deal is still possible, but the sides have come to loathe each other.
sentences.chinese: 协议仍存可能，只是双方已经开始恶语相向。

sentences.english: Enduring verbal abuse is also a kind of spiritual practice.
sentences.chinese: 面对恶言恶语，也是一种修行。

sentences.english: Sometimes words hurt more than swords.
sentences.chinese: 恶语有时伤人比刀剑更厉害。

sentences.english: Bad words hurt people; good words warm people.
sentences.chinese: 恶语一出话伤人，好话一句暖人心。

sentences.english: The deal emerged late on Saturday after fractious public exchanges earlier in the day between Republicans and Democrats.
sentences.chinese: 在周六共和党和民主党恶语相向以后，协议浮出水面。

sentences.english: Respond to the content of your boss's tirade, not the curses.
sentences.chinese: 只可回应你老板所责骂的事，而不回应他的恶言恶语。

sentences.english: Many words cut (or hurt) more than swords.
For your hands are defiled with blood, and your fingers with iniquity: your lips have spoken lies, and your tongue uttereth iniquity.
sentences.chinese: 你们的口唇说了谎言，你们的舌头吐出了恶语。

sentences.english: He wasn't disturbed by the wicked words.
sentences.chinese: 他没受那些恶言恶语的干扰。

sentences.english: That woman has an evil tongue.
sentences.chinese: 那女人有一张惯于恶语中伤的嘴。

sentences.english: Even reproofs from authority, ought to be grave, and not taunting.
sentences.chinese: 即使上官申斥，亦宜出之以严肃，而不应恶语伤人。

definition: to insult/to direct bad language at sb/to slag off
to hurl abuse/to deride/to call sb names
frigid irony and scorching satire (idiom); to mock and ridicule
unkind/harsh/cutting/mean/acrimony/to embezzle by making illegal deductions
to insult/to direct bad language at sb/to slag off
